etymologies: Middle English rime, from Old French, from medieval Latin rithmus, via Latin from Greek rhuthmos (see rhythm). The current spelling was introduced in the early 17th century under the influence of rhythm

definitions: correspondence of sound between words or the endings of words, especially when these are used at the ends of lines of poetry

examples.text: poetic features such as rhythm, rhyme, and alliteration

definitions: a short poem in which the sound of the word or syllable at the end of each line corresponds with that at the end of another
shortDefinitions: short poem in which sound of word or syllable at end of each line corresponds with that at end of another

definitions: poetry or verse marked by rhyme

examples.text: the clues were written in rhyme

definitions: a word that has the same sound as another

examples.text: “gravel” can be interpreted as an absurd rhyme for “travel”

shortDefinitions: word that has same sound as another

definitions: (of a word, syllable, or line) have or end with a sound that corresponds to another
shortDefinitions: (of word, syllable, or line) have or end with sound that corresponds to another

definitions: (of a poem or song) be composed of lines that end in words or syllables with sounds that correspond with those at the ends of other lines

examples.text: the poem would have been better if it had rhymed

shortDefinitions: (of poem or song) be composed in rhyme

definitions: put a word together with (another word that has a corresponding sound), as when writing poetry

examples.text: I'm not sure about rhyming perestroika with balalaika

shortDefinitions: put word together with, as when writing poetry
